titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Morning visit from the Revd. Mr. Matthews, with the Roman Catholic Bishop of Detroit— The Bishop is acquainted with Mr George Boyd, and his family at Green Bay—and was also acquainted with Mr Thomas B. Johnson some years ago at Rome. The Bishop had called me out from my Seat in the House a few days since, and said he wished to have it in his power, on his return to Michigan, to inform Coll. Boyd and his family that he had seen their relations here— I had invited him to come to my house, and My wife and Mary came down and conversed with him and Mr Matthews, Priest of the Roman Catholic Church here— The business that occupied the House was the army and Indian and Navy Appropriation Bills.— The first was passed without debate and almost without observation— Cushing made a set Speech, avowedly not for the House but for home consumption—not against the Indian Appropriation Bill, but against our treatment of the Indians, an exhausted and altogether useless theme of declamation. Yet it gave rise to a sharp debate in which Dawson, Glascock, Holsey and above all the new member from Georgia Alford, came down with the tomahawk and scalping knife arguments, upon Cushing, and Horace Everett and Grennell— Alford has been himself in the Indian wars; lives within 25 Miles of the Indian borders, and could not conceive how any man could have any sympathy with Indians— He said he was much indisposed, and was not in voice or else he would give the house a specimen of the War-whoops. He declared himself an opposition man; but that the Government in their treatment of the Indians were not to blame— Adjourned about 5— I wrote an address to the Petitioners for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia, from to the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts for publication in the Quincy Patriot.

Persico had met me yesterday morning at the door of the House and asked me to call at his lodgings Mrs Carlisle’s to sit or stand for him to work on his marble bust of me— I promised to come not recollecting my engagement at ten this Morning with the Committee of Manufactures— I called this morning on Persico, and told him, I would come again to-morrow— Met the Committee at ten Adams, Denny, Fowler, Lee, Webster, Whittlesey—absent Bynum, Granger and M’Comas— I was instructed to ask to be discharged from the further consideration of George Whitman to import iron for two Steam-boats free of duty— A Baron Roenne the Prussian Minister Resident’s Letter, soliciting the repeal of the duty upon linen tapes was postponed— At the House there was a bill from the Senate purporting to be for the relief of Andrew Knox, upon a Land claim; but which had a second Section altogether of a public nature, which Huntsman moved to refer to the Committee of private Land-claims, and I to a committee of the whole; but it only served to drive the bill through its second and third reading without amendment.— Among the Reports of Committees was one from M’Keon, of the Committee of Commerce with a bill abolishing Protections for American Seamen, and to furnish them with Passports—read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union— I made the report from the Committee of Manufactures unfavourable to the petition of George Whitman— The Indian Appropriation Bill was taken up, and after Speeches from Grennell and Alford, and Horace Everett past— Then the Navy Appropriation Bill, upon which Jarvis moved to reduce by 150000 dollars the sum for the exploring South Sea expedition and censured bitterly the President and the Secretary of the Navy both for extravagance and ignorance in the manner of fitting out this expedition— S. C. Phillips and I answered Jarvis and Cambreleng and supported the appropriation— Adjourned near 5— Elizabeth Adams spent the Evening at Mrs W. S. Smith’s—

6. VI:15. Monday— At the House— Petition day— I presented Petitions of Joseph Rolette &c, Crawford County, Wisconsin Territory—of Huldah Pennyman— Petition Letter of Elias Ware, and Petition of David Loud, a Soldier of the late War—all referred— Then 32. Abolition Petitions. laid on the Table— Stated the liability to imposition occasioned by the order of 18. Jany and my suspicions of the genuineness of the two last petitions that I had in my hands— Petition of 9 women of Fredericksburg—laid on the table— Petition from Slaves— I asked the Speaker whether it came within the order of the 18. Jany— Said he must consult the House— Stormy debate succession of motions to bring me to the bar— Haynes, Waddy Thompson—Lewis, Dromgoole—Granger, Abijah Mann, Cambreleng—adjourned between 5 and 6. Patton’s motion by suspension of the Rules—to take the Petitions of the women off the files and return it to me—superseded by the privileged question.— Struggle to prevent me from presenting Petitions, other than from my own State—decision of the Speaker, confirmed—

At the House, Resolutions against me resumed—Jenifer—W. Thompson accepts Dromgoole’s amendment— Bynum, Milligan moves to lay on the table to which I object— Levi Lincoln—Cushing—H. L. Pinckney—debate through the day adjourn at 6.

At the House, my trial was postponed— At 12. O’Clock The Senate came in, and the votes for the Election of President and Vice-President of the United States were opened and counted— Martin Van Buren of New-York, was proclaimed elected President of the United States for four years from the 3d. of March next— One vote was
was wanting for the election of Richard M. Johnson of Kentuckey as Vice-President, but the Senate after separating from the House elected him— The votes of Michigan were conditionally counted— Elizabeth C. Adams and Elizabeth De Wint went with me to the House, and I obtained Seats for them in the Gallery—a joint Committee was appointed to inform Mr Van Buren of his election—

Third day of my trial— Two Resolutions offered by Patton as amendments to amendments of Waddy Thompson’s Resolution of censure— Vanderpoel moved the Previous Question—to cut me off from my defence—but the house did not sustain him 79 to 100— I made my defence and then by previous question the questions on Patton’s two resolutions were taken, and rejected the first 92 to 103 the secondThen a Resolution was passed to bring Reuben M Whitney to the Bar for a contempt in refusing to appear before Wise’s Committee of investigation—
